LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

telecommunication  network,  and 

Digicel  (PNG)  Limited,  a  limited-liability  company  incorporated  in 
Papua New Guinea (PNG)  
 
Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector  (subsector):  Transport,  and  information  and  communication 
technology (information and communication technology) 
Themes  (subthemes):  Economic  growth  (promoting  economic 
efficiency  and  enabling  business  environment),  private  sector 
development (private sector investment) 
Location impact: Rural (high) and urban (high) 
Partnership: Digicel group  
 
Environment: C 
Involuntary resettlement: C 
Indigenous peoples: C  
 
The  Project  is  (i)  an  expansion  and  improvement  of  the  Borrower’s 
(ii)  an 
nationwide  mobile 
enhancement of its mobile telecommunication services in PNG.  
 
The  proposed  loan  will  be  up  to  $25  million  funded  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).  
 
(i)  The  Project  will  provide  an  expansion  of  affordable  telecom 
service, particularly for low-income users.  
(ii)  The  Project  will  improve  the  accessibility  and  quality  of  telecom 
services in PNG, particularly in remote and rural areas.  
(iii) The increased affordability and improved accessibility will enable 
inclusive  economic  growth  by  facilitating  access  to  markets  and 
information  and  developing  other  businesses  relying  on  telecom 
service.  
(iv) ADB’s support to the Borrower, which exemplifies good corporate 
governance and strong social responsibility, will promote similar good 
practices in the private sector. 
(v)  Improved  network  will  enable  better  access  to  information, 
including for public service delivery, education, health, and security. 
(vi) The  Project  will  provide  direct  employment  opportunities, 
to  staff,  and  associated 
managerial 
business  opportunities  to  dealers  and  contractors  in  the  country’s 
underdeveloped areas. 
 
Digicel Pacific Limited, a company majority owned and controlled by 
Denis O’Brien as the founder of Digicel group

ADB  can  add  to  the  Project  and  the  Project’s  development  impacts 
and demonstration effects. ADB will add value through (i) catalyzing, 
as a regional multilateral agency and reputable infrastructure lender,

 1 

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  Digicel  (PNG)  Limited  (the  Borrower)  for  the  Digicel  Mobile  Telecommunication  Expansion 
Project  in  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG).  The  Borrower  will  use  the  proceeds  of  the  loan  to  (i) 
expand and improve its existing nationwide mobile telecommunication network, and (ii) enhance 
mobile  telecommunication  services  in  PNG.  The  Project  will  be  the  first  private  sector 
investment by Asian Development Bank (ADB) in PNG and its first private sector infrastructure 
investment in the Pacific region.  
 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

Sector Background  

Project Identification and Selection 

A. 
 
2. 
The Project targets expansion of the Borrower’s existing network and enhancement of its 
affordable telecommunication services across PNG, where the demand is growing rapidly. The 
assessment  indicates  that  the  Project  is  bankable  and  the  development  impact  is  substantial. 
ADB’s  role  in  the  Project  would  be  catalytic  and  consistent  with  ADB’s  crisis  response. 
Therefore,  the  Project  was  selected  for  processing  and  consideration  by  the  ADB  Board  of 
Directors. 
 
B. 
 
3. 
PNG,  with  a  population  of  about  6  million,  is  the  largest  economy  in  ADB’s  Pacific 
region.  Before  2007,  as  in  the  other  Pacific  island  countries,  the  telecommunication  market  in 
PNG  was  dominated  by  a  large  state-owned  enterprise,  Telikom  PNG.  With  fixed-line 
penetration  of  slightly  more  than  1%  and  mobile  penetration  of  less  than  5%  (prior  to  the 
Borrower’s launch), the country was among those having insufficient telecommunication access 
in  the  world.  The  telecommunication  market  in  PNG  could  be  characterized  as  having  (i)  high 
demand  for  affordable  services,  (ii)  widespread  consumer  dissatisfaction,  and  (iii)  high  tariffs 
and low telephony penetration. 
 
Lack  of  reliable  fixed-line  infrastructure,  combined  with  cheaper  installation  costs  for 
4. 
mobile  telecommunication,  has  led  to  fixed-to-mobile  substitution.  Deregulation  of  the 
telecommunication industry is likely to be imminent across the Pacific region, including PNG. In 
2002,  the  National  Executive  Council  (NEC)  of  PNG  announced  planned  liberalization  of  the 
telecommunication sector from October 2007. In September 2006, the Borrower was confirmed 
to  be  licensed  for  mobile  telecommunication  operations  in  PNG  with  a  start  in  2007.  The 
Borrower  launched  its  service  in  July  2007.  Presently,  the  market  is  divided  by  the  Borrower, 
Telikom  PNG  (fixed  line  operator)  and  Bemobile  Ltd  (mobile  operator which  is  50%  owned  by 
Telikom PNG). 
 
5. 
Demand.  The  current  mobile  penetration  rate  in  PNG  is  approximately  18%,  which 
indicates the market is still underserved. 1 The global mobile penetration rate exceeded 60% at 
the  beginning  of  2009,  albeit  with  a  certain  shrinkage  in  the  past  several  months  due  to  the 
global  economic  crisis.  The  mobile  penetration  rates  in  others  of  ADB’s  developing  member 
countries are as follow: Afghanistan (35% in 2007), Azerbaijan (25% in 2005), Fiji Islands (34% 

                                                 
1   Due  to  a  lack  of  up-to-date,  reliable  statistical  data,  it  is  difficult  to  estimate  accurately  the  demand  for  mobile 
telecommunication  service  in  PNG  or  in  any  specific  province  or  city.  The  demand  analysis  focuses  on  the  low 
mobile penetration rate in PNG compared to other developing markets, which is indicative of strong unmet demand.  

 

 2 

 

in  2008),  Indonesia  (57%  in  2009),  Philippines  (76%  in  2008),  and  Samoa  (50%  in  2008). 
Therefore, the mobile telecommunication market in PNG is expected to grow. In addition to the 
existing  market  that  has  not  been  served,  demand  growth  will  be  mainly  from  two  groups:  (i) 
potential customers who can afford and are willing to own mobile phones but are not covered by 
any mobile network, and (ii) potential customers who currently cannot afford mobile phones but 
are  already  within  mobile  coverage.  Further  demand  will  emerge  gradually  as  a  real  market 
takes shape, coverage expands, and tariffs are reduced due to increasing competition.  
 
Reforms.  In  March  2009,  NEC  approved  a  comprehensive  set  of  reforms  for  the 
6. 
telecommunications sector by endorsing the National ICT Policy Phase 2 Reforms Final Report 
(the NICT Report),2 developed by the Department of Communication & Information. The report 
sets out a path for staged introduction of open competition in PNG’s telecommunications sector. 
In summary, the following reforms were adopted by NEC: (i) introduction of a new technology-
neutral  horizontal  licensing  regime,  (ii)  liberalization  of  the  international  telecommunications 
gateway,  (iii)  establishment  of  a  new  wholesale  access  and  interconnection  regime,  (iv) 
development  of  a  new  universal  access  scheme  to  provide  a  funding  mechanism  for 
telecommunication projects in areas where commercial investment is not viable, and (v) creation 
of  a  new  information  and  communication  technology  regulator  to  be  known  as  the  National 
Information and Communication Technology Authority.  
 
7. 
with the intention of giving legislative effect to the NICT Report. 
 
8. 
As part of the proposed new licensing regime, current licensees (including the Borrower) 
will be encouraged to migrate to the new set of licenses on a voluntary basis within a year of the 
NICT  Bill's  becoming  law.  The  bill,  when  enacted,  will  ensure  that  the  new  licenses  will  be 
issued on terms at least to the same extent permitted by the existing license.  
 
ADB’s  involvement  in  the  telecommunications  sector  to  date  has  been  confined  to 
9. 
supporting  the  competition  regulator,  the  ICCC,  in  developing  telecommunications  industry 
codes  of  practice  and  interconnection  determinations.  Under  the  proposed  new  regulatory 
regime, ICCC’s operating licensing functions and PANGTEL’s technical licensing functions will 
be transferred to the National Information and Communication Technology Authority, which will 
be  established  as  the  one  independent  telecommunications  regulator.    PANGTEL  will  be 
dissolved but the ICCC will remain the general competition regulator. 
 
 
C. 
 

 A  National  Information  and  Communications  Technology  Bill  (NICT  Bill)  was  drafted 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

10. 
The Project is consistent with ADB’s long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 
2020),  which  identifies  infrastructure  as  one  of  the  five  core  areas  where  ADB  will  employ  its 
financial  and  institutional  resources  in  order  to maximize  results,  efficiency,  and  impact.3  ADB 
will  invest  in  infrastructure  to  improve  transport  and  communication  connectivity  within  and 
between  its  developing  member  countries.  Under  Strategy  2020,  ADB’s  infrastructure 
operations will emphasize public-private partnerships and private sector engagement.  
                                                 
2  Government of PNG. 2009. National ICT Policy Phase 2 Reforms Final Report. Port Moresby. 
 
3  ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  2008–2020. 

Manila. 

 

   3 

 
11. 
Under Strategy 2020, inclusive growth is one of three complementary strategic agendas 
upon  which  ADB  decided  to  focus.  The  Project  will  directly  improve  the  poor’s  access  to 
markets and basic productive assets, thereby helping to achieve inclusive growth in PNG.  
  

2. 

Consistency with the Country Strategy 

The Project is in line with ADB’s Pacific Strategy4 and its country strategy and program5 
12. 
(CSP)  in  PNG.  One  key  result  area  as  identified  by  ADB  in  the  Pacific  Strategy  is  improved 
provision,  operation,  and  maintenance  of  physical  infrastructure.  That  is  very  much  needed  in 
order  to  support  an  environment  conducive  to  the  private  sector.  In  the  new  Pacific  Strategy, 
which  is  close  to  completion,  information  and  communication  technology  is  one  of  the 
operational priorities. In the latest CSP midterm review, published in July 2009, ADB proposed 
four refinements in the remaining CSP period, including an enhanced role for the private sector, 
and it planned to explore opportunities for ADB’s private sector operations in PNG with a focus 
on the infrastructure and energy sectors. 6 
 

3. 

Consistency with Other Relevant ADB Operations 

13. 
The  Project  complements  ADB’s  continuous  effort  regarding  telecommunication  sector 
reforms  in  PNG.  ADB’s  involvement  in  PNG’s  telecommunication  sector  to  date  has  been 
confined to support to ICCC.7 ADB was also involved in the public consultation of the proposed 
NICT  Bill.  As  a  lender  to  the  Project,  ADB  will  lend  its  support  to  the  effort  to  ensure  the 
requirements of the NICT Report are fully expressed in the NICT Bill when it is enacted. 
 

III. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Description 

1. 

The Sponsor and Borrower 

a. 

Sponsor 

 
14. 
The Sponsor, Digicel Pacific Limited, is an affiliate of Digicel Group Limited and Digicel 
Holdings (Central America) Limited, which together control the Digicel group’s operations in the 
Caribbean and Central America. The Digicel brand was started in Jamaica in April 2001, and it 
has rapidly gained market share in every country it has entered to date.  
 
15. 
The Sponsor is a holding company for its group’s South Pacific operations, which cover 
five  markets  including  Fiji  Islands,  PNG,  Samoa,  Tonga,  and  Vanuatu.  In  2006,  Digicel  was 
launched  in  Samoa,  and  it  continues  to  enjoy  steady  growth  there.  The  Sponsor,  via  the 
Borrower,  launched  its  mobile  telecommunication  business  in  PNG  in  July  2007.  In  2008,  the 
Sponsor launched business in Fiji Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu.  
 
The  Digicel  brand  is  renowned  among  its  customers  for  competitive  rates,  wide 
16. 
coverage, good customer care, a wide variety of products and services, up-to-date technology 

                                                 
4  ADB. 2004. Responding to the Priorities of the Poor: A Pacific Strategy for ADB (2005–2009). Manila. 
5  ADB. 2006. Country Strategy and Program for Papua New Guinea (2006–2010). Manila. 
6  ADB. 2009. Country Strategy and Program Midterm Review for Papua New Guinea (2006–2010). Manila.  
7   ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to Papua New Guinea for Policy for Private Sector Development. Manila. 

 

 4 

 

and a good selection of handsets, as well as community support and development through the 
Digicel Foundation. 
 

Borrower 

b. 
 

17. 
Since  its  launch  in  July  2007,  the  Borrower,  Digicel  PNG  Limited,  has  experienced 
significant  growth.  Key  factors  for  the  Borrower’s  success  are  (i)  continuous  investment  in 
network expansion and new technology, (ii) being first-to-market with new products and services, 
(iii)  a  retail  presence  and  strategy,  (iv)  24/7  customer  care,  (v)  an  experienced  management 
team,  and  (vi)  community  activities.  These  together  constitute  the  successful  business  model 
and practices carried over from Digicel’s experience in the Caribbean.  
 
The  Borrower’s  management  team  has  significant  experience  in  the  telecom  industry 
18. 
and in Digicel’s Caribbean business. Supported comes from the group’s regional management 
team as well as the broader resources and experience of its markets globally.   As  a 
result, 
the Borrower is expected to maintain its competitive advantages and to continue its success in 
PNG, even though telecom reform in PNG will make competition keener.  
 
19. 
reliable  and  affordable  mobile 
telecommunication services to a market. The increasing competition will benefit customers, and 
particularly the poor. 
 

the  benefits  of 

The  Borrower 

is  bringing 

2. 

Project Design 

The  Borrower’s  existing  network  in  PNG  is  based  on  the  Global  System  for  Mobile-

20. 
communications, the most popular standard for mobile telecom in the world. 
 
21. 
The Project expands the Borrower’s network capacity. The Borrower will add additional 
switches, upgrade its billing system, and expand its network coverage. Most of the new network 
sites are in rural areas without basic telecom infrastructure. Although the equipment, the costs 
of  which  represent  about  60%  of  the  total  capital  expenditure,  was  purchased  from  foreign 
suppliers,  the  civil  works  and  other  services  have  been  contracted  to  local  contractors  and 
suppliers, which directly benefit the local economy. 
 

3. 

Project Outputs and Outcome 

The  Project  will  result  in  improved  and  expanded  mobile  telecommunication  network 
22. 
facilities,  thus  enabling  more  subscribers  to  afford  and  use  telecommunication  services  in  line 
with international standards. The outcome of the Project will be increased penetration of high-
quality, affordable mobile telecommunication services in PNG.  
 
23. 
training program for college graduates to develop core competence within the local staff.  
 
B. 

The Project will directly create more than 100 new jobs. The Borrower has introduced a 

Development Impact 

1. 

Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Reduction 

 
Since  its  launch,  the  Borrower  has  substantially  lowered  the  mobile  calling  prices  in 
24. 
PNG.  Through  implementing  the  Project,  tariffs  are  expected  to  continuously  decrease  as  the 
result  of  enhanced  economies  of  scale  and  increased  competition.  Hence,  the  Project  will 

 

   5 

increase the affordability of telecom services, and particularly for low-income users across the 
country.  The  Project  will  moreover  expand  the  network  coverage  in  PNG,  and  the  improved 
accessibility will most benefit users in rural, remote areas, where there is limited telecom service 
at present. The increased affordability and improved accessibility will enable inclusive economic 
growth by facilitating access to markets and information, such as by providing remote access to 
bank accounts and updated market information for fishermen and farmers.  
 
25. 
The  Project  will  significantly  improve  the  Borrower’s  existing  network.  After  project 
implementation, customers will enjoy better access to information, including in relation to public 
services, education, health, and security. For an island developing country, such information as 
weather forecasts or natural disaster alerts is critical to the general public, particularly the poor. 
Following  completion  of  the  Project,  more  villages  which  have  roads  but  have  not  had 
telephones,  will  be  able  to  use  ambulance  services  because  villagers  will  be  able  to  call  the 
services  directly.  Also,  in  the  past  a  village  school  in  the  Highlands  region  could  close  for 
several days just because the teacher needed to go to a bank to confirm a wage credit (and this 
took  so  long,  due  to  the  lack  of  transport  infrastructure).  With  the  short  messaging  system 
banking service provided by the Borrower and its partner banks, commuting time will be saved.  

 
26. 
The  Project  supports  the  Government’s  Medium  Term  Development  Strategy  2005–
2010,8  which  focuses,  as  a  primary  goal,  on  improving  living  standards  in  the  country.  That 
strategy strongly promotes fostering rural development and an enabling business environment. 
By improving nationwide telecommunication infrastructure and expanding access in rural areas, 
the Project will contribute to growth of the telecommunication sector in a country with growing 
demand  from  the  entire  society  for reliable  and  affordable mobile  telecommunication  services. 
As all other sectors in PNG will benefit from enhanced telecommunication services, the Project 
will extend yet further the Borrower’s contribution to economic growth and development in PNG. 
 

2. 

Private Sector Development 

 
27. 
The Project will also provide direct training and development, employment, and business 
opportunities  to  staff,  dealers,  and  contractors  in  underdeveloped  areas  of  the  country.  The 
Borrower has been recognized as a leading example of good corporate governance and strong 
social  responsibility.  ADB’s  support  to  the  Borrower  will  promote  similar  good  practices  in  the 
private sector, the role of which is being enhanced in PNG. 
 

 

C. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Licenses and Permits 

The principal licenses and permits underpinning the Borrower’s operations are (i) a 10-
39. 
year  license  to  operate  mobile  telecommunication  networks  in  PNG,  which  was  granted  in 
March  2007  by  the  ICCC,  the  commercial  regulator  and  licensing  authority;  and  (ii)  a  10-year 
spectrum usage agreement with PANGTEL, the technical regulator, granted in November 2008. 
The license and agreement together give the Borrower a nonexclusive right to provide wireless 
voice  and  data  telecommunication  services  based  on  the  Global  System  for  Mobile 
communications technology and standards in PNG. 
 
                                                 
8 Government  of  PNG.  2004.  The  Medium  Term  Development  Strategy  2005–2010:  "Our  Plan  for  Economic  and 

Social Advancement." Port Moresby. 

 

 

 6 

 

Another  important  permit  is  that  for  the  Borrower  to  operate  an  international  gateway 
40. 
(IGW).  The  ICCC  consented  to  the  Borrower’s  operating  its  own  international  gateway  (thus 
granting an IGW Permit) in July 2007.  
 

2. 

Interconnection 

41. 
Another  key  agreement  is  that  for  the  Borrower’s  right  to  interconnect  its  facilities  to 
Telikom  PNG’s  network.  The  Borrower  has  a  legal  right  to  interconnect  to  Telikom  PNG’s 
network under the Telecommunications Act 1996 on terms to be agreed by the parties.  
 

3. 

Construction Arrangements 

The Project expands the Borrower’s existing network by increasing sites, most of which 
42. 
are in rural areas. All the contractors and equipment suppliers are reputable and were involved 
in the works at the existing sites.  

 
Site construction, backbone expansion, and system upgrade will be done simultaneously. 
43. 
The  Project  is  expected  to  be  completed  in  short  time  due  to  limited  civil  works  while  the 
equipment and system have been ordered in advance. The construction for each individual site 
can be completed in about 2–3 weeks while many sites are constructed simultaneously. Due to 
the nature of the construction works and the previous experience of contractors and suppliers, 
no system-wide delay is likely. 

 
4. 

Operations Arrangements 

44. 
The  Borrower’s  business  is  highly  automated.  Apart  from  its  headquarters  in  Port 
Moresby and regional key switches in other cities, all base stations or transmission towers in the 
backbone  operate  unattended  and  are  fully  automated.  All  calls  and  data  services  are 
processed  by  computers.  The  major  labor-intensive  process  is  customer  service.  More  staffs 
are being recruited and trained in the customer service call center. 
 
45. 
The  Borrower’s  subscriber  base  is  dominated  by  prepaid  customers.  Prepaid  accounts 
can  be  recharged  by  purchasing  top-up  cards  available  in  various  kinds  of  shops  or  buying 
loads for cash in Digicel retail stores, with a minimum load of just K1. A postpaid contract, which 
is  mainly  offered  to  large  corporations,  is  secured  by  a  significant  deposit.  Therefore,  the 
Borrower bears no payment risk from its subscribers.  
 
46. 
Handsets  are  sold  from  as  low  as  K49,  with  a  SIM  card  and  limited  calling  minutes 
included.  Subsidies  are  offered  on  the  low-end  handsets  in  order  to  drive  subscriber  growth. 
The phones are locked, and can only be used by Digicel’s subscribers. With the launch of both 
internet-enabled  mobile  phones  and  Blackberry  handsets,  there  has  been  an  increase  in  the 
demand for medium- and high-end handsets which do not require subsidy.  
  
47. 
Since many sites are in rural areas where no power grid is nearby, diesel generators are 
used for power supply in the existing network. Local maintenance contractors must go to those 
sites once every 6–8 weeks to refill diesel. This is the only significant maintenance needed for 
the  sites.  Under  the  Project,  many  new  sites  will  install  solar  panels  as  the  primary  power 
source  with  diesel  generators  as  backup.  These  new  sites  are  more  environmentally  friendly 
and require even less maintenance.  
 

 

   7 

5. 

Anticorruption  and  Combating  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of 
Terrorism 

48. 
The  Borrower  was  advised  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date) 
and policy relating to the Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism (2003). 
Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will 
require  the  Borrower  to  institute,  maintain,  and  comply  with  internal  procedures  and  controls 
following international best practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption or money 
laundering  activities  or  the  financing  of  terrorism  and  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from 
engaging in such activities. The loan documentation between ADB and the Borrower will further 
allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings. 
 

6. 

Project Performance Monitoring, Reporting, and Evaluation 

49. 
The Borrower will continue to provide to the lenders, including ADB, quarterly unaudited 
financial  statements,  quarterly  operations  reports,  annual  audited  financial  statements,  annual 
operations  reports,  annual  environmental  and  social  monitoring  reports,  and  annual  business 
plans. It must report any important changes. ADB will monitor the Project vis-à-vis the business 
plans, using information from its own sources and the public domain. Evaluation of the Project 
will be on three levels: (i) the success of the Project, (ii) economic growth in PNG generally, and 
(iii) private sector development in PNG. . 
 
 

IV. 

THE PROPOSED ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

1. 

Instrument and Amount 

50. 
The  proposed  ADB  assistance  for  the  Project  will  comprise  a  direct  loan  of  up  to  $25 
million.  The  loan  will  be  funded  using  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  without  government 
guarantee.   
 
B. 

Justification for ADB Assistance 

51. 
ADB’s  potential  assistance  for  the  Project  will  be  justified  based  on  its  value-added, 
development  impacts  and  demonstration  effects.  It  supports  the  Government’s  development 
plans and ADB’s operational strategies. In the Project, ADB will add value by: 
 

(i) 

(ii) 

Catalyzing  further  commercial  financing  to  a  thriving  sector  in  PNG.  The  local 
debt market is limited at present, particularly for medium-term financing. Offshore 
commercial  and  export  credit  sources  are  also  limited  in  extending  uncovered 
financing to businesses in PNG. The global financial crisis has further tightened 
PNG’s access to liquidity. ADB’s role in the Project is therefore considered to be 
critical  in  catalyzing  medium-term  commercial  debt  financing  and  mitigating  the 
effects of the current global financial crisis.  
Demonstrating  support  for  a  sustainable  private  sector  participation  with  good 
corporate  governance  and  strong  social  responsibility  in  PNG  and  the  Pacific 
region  (of  which  there  are  not  many),  encouraging  entrepreneurs  and  financial 
investors to consider investments in key sectors in PNG and the Pacific region, 
and inducing competitors to improve their service and performance. 

 

 8 

 

 
 

(iii) 

Reflecting the strong commitment  of ADB’s private sector operations to support 
small-scale economies within its developing member countries. In particular, the 
Project  helps  to  encourage  the  transfer  of  capital,  technology,  and  experience 
from an experienced international sponsor to a developing member country.  

V. 

ASSURANCES 

Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank, 9   the 
52. 
Government has been requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed assistance 
to  the  Borrower.  No  funding  will  be  disbursed  until  ADB  receives  such  confirmation.  ADB  will 
enter  into  finance  documents  acceptable  to  ADB  following  the  approval  of  the  proposed 
financing by ADB’s Board of Directors.  
 
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

53. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of  up  to 
$25,000,000  to  Digicel  (PNG)  Limited  for  the  Digicel  Mobile  Telecommunication  Expansion 
Project from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be 
reported to the Board. 
 
 
 
 

Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 

 

 
26 October 2009 
 

 

                                                
 
9  ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.
